revisions.rev:
{{Infobox Civil Conflict | title = Occupy Oakland | partof = the [[Occupy movement]] | image =[[File:Occupy Oakland 99% signs.jpg|300px]] | caption = Occupy Oakland on November 2, 2011 | date = October 10, 2011 â Present Day
({{Age in days|2011|10|10}} days) | place = [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[California]] | coordinates = | causes = *[[Wealth inequality in the United States|Wealth Inequality]] *[[Corporatism|Corporatism]] | status = On Going | goals = | result = | methods = *[[Civil Disobedience]] *[[Occupation (protest)|Occupation]] *[[Picketing (protest)|Picketing]] *[[General Strike]] |side1= |side2= *Oakland City Government *[[Oakland Police Department]] | side3 = |leadfigures1= No Central Leadership |leadfigures2= *[[Jean Quan|Mayor Jean Quan]] *Interim Police Chief Howard Jordan *City Administrator Deanna Santana | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1=
'''Arrests:'''105+
'''Injuries:'''4+
| casualties2= | casualties3 = | casualties_label= Arrests/Injuries | notes = }} '''Occupy Oakland''' is a series of [[Demonstration (people)|demonstrations]] including the [[Occupation (protest)|occupation]] of public spaces that began in [[downtown Oakland]] at [[Frank H. Ogawa Plaza]] in front of [[Oakland City Hall]] in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[California]] on October 10, 2011. It is allied with the [[Occupy Wall Street]] movement in New York City and is one of several [[Occupy movement]] sites in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. Other sites included [[Occupy San Francisco]], [[Occupy San Jose]] and [[Occupy Cal]]. Occupy Oakland began as a protest encampment at Frank H. Ogawa Plaza. It was cleared out by multiple law enforcement agencies on October 25, 2011.{{cite news|last=Bulwa|first=Demian|title=Police clear Occupy Oakland camps, arrest dozens|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/25/BAUB1LLTC9.DTL|accessdate=October 25, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=October 25, 2011}} That evening when protesters tried to reclaim the site, clashes between police and protesters resulted in multiple injuries and over 100 arrests. Scott Olsen, an Iraq war veteran, suffered a skull fracture allegedly caused by a police projectile. His injury came to national attention and became a rallying cry for the Occupy movement. The site was re-occupied by protesters the next evening. The [[2011 Oakland general strike|general strike]] brought thousands of demonstrators to downtown Oakland for a day of action, including a march to the [[Port of Oakland]] which was forced to shut down operations. That evening, clashes between protesters and police again occurred when protesters occupied a vacant building in downtown Oakland. Two more protesters, one of whom is an Iraq War veteran, were seriously hurt by police and both actions were captured on video. Investigations into the alleged police misconduct are being conducted by the Oakland Police department, the ACLU, and the National Lawyers Guild. Law enforcement once again cleared the protest encampment at Frank Ogawa Plaza on November 14, 2011. Mayor Jean Quanâs decision to allow the police intervention resulted in the resignation of the mayor's unpaid legal adviser Dan Siegel and Deputy Mayor Sharon Cornu.{{cite news|last=Walter|first=Shoshana|title=2 Top Quan Aides Resign|url=http://www.baycitizen.org/occupy-movement/story/quans-deputy-mayor-resigns/|accessdate=November 16, 2011|newspaper=The Bay Citizen|date=November 14, 2011}} Other protest encampments were created and subsequently dismantled by law enforcement. The last encampment at Snow Park was cleared after an early morning raid on November 21, 2011. The movement was left with no physical presence occupying any public space overnight in the city of Oakland. {{cite news|last=Kane|first=Will|title=Police clear out last Occupy Oakland camp|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/21/BAO61M24MU.DTL|accessdate=November 21, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 21, 2011}} On November 29, demonstrators began a 24/7 vigil at the plaza.{{cite news|last=Colin|first=Chris|title=A teepee grows in Oakland|url=http://www.salon.com/2011/11/30/a_teepee_grows_in_oakland/singleton/|accessdate=December 3 2011|newspaper=Salon|date=November 30, 2011}} ==Occupation sites== ===Frank H. Ogawa Plaza === [[File:Ogawa Plaza.png|thumb|right|An overhead layout of Frank H. Ogawa plaza.]] [[File:Occupy Oakland Poster.jpg|thumb|right|Occupy Oakland poster announcing the October 22 march.]] ====First occupation==== The first occupation lasted for 15 days from October 10 to October 25. [[Frank H. Ogawa Plaza]], was symbolically renamed "Oscar Grant Plaza" by the protestors, referring to [[Oscar Grant]], a young Oakland man killed by a [[BART]] police officer in 2009, an incident that became the catalyst for major protests during 2009 and 2010. {{cite news|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/abraham/2011/10/30/occupy-oakland-the-oscar-grant-frank-ogawa-plaza-issue/|title=Occupy Oakland: The Oscar Grant / Frank Ogawa Plaza Issue|first=Zennie|last=Abraham|date=October 30, 2011|publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|accessdate=October 30, 2011}} The occupation of Frank Ogawa Plaza officially began at 4 p.m. on October 10, 2011, with a rally attended by hundreds of supporters. This rally was held in tandem with [[Indigenous People's Day]], both as a statement of solidarity and an expression that this action firmly situated itself against colonialism and nation states.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} The first general assembly, an open democratic meeting based on [[Occupy Wall Street]]'s New York general assembly, was held in the plaza amphitheater at 6 p.m. and a couple dozen protesters set up tents that evening. The amphitheater continues to be used as the general assembly location on Sunday, Monday, Wednesday and Friday evenings at 6 p.m.{{cite web|title=Occupy Oakland|url=http://www.occupyoakland.org/|accessdate=November 21, 2011}} Occupy Oakland planned and organized a number of [[direct actions]] including marches and rallies and guest speakers to build support for the movement. On October 14, protesters participated in a short march during rush hour.{{cite news|last=Quintana|first=Sergio|title=Occupy Oakland holds short march during rush hour|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8392891|accessdate=October 18, 2011|newspaper=KGO|date=October 15, 2011}} The following weekend, around 2,500 people, including actor and activist [[Danny Glover]], came out for a Saturday march and rally to show their support for Occupy Oakland.{{cite news|title=Organizers say thousands took part in Oakland rally|url=http://www.ktvu.com/news/29497557/detail.html|accessdate=October 18, 2011|newspaper=KTVU|date=October 15, 2011}} On October 17, the [[2009â2011 detention of American hikers by Iran|three American hikers recently freed from an Iranian prison]] made their first West Coast speaking appearance at Occupy Oakland, drawing an audience of around 300 people.{{cite web|last=Bender|first=Kristine J.|title=Freed American hikers speak to Occupy Oakland on Monday night|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19132953?nclick_check=1|work=Republished by San Jose Mercury News|publisher=[[Oakland Tribune]]|accessdate=22 November 2011|month=October 18|year=2011}} A diverse array of people inhabited the camp, ranging from students and professionals to unemployed workers and homeless people.{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Scott|title=Life at Occupy Oakland attracts range of characters|url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/localnews/ci_19141204|accessdate=October 23, 2011|newspaper=Oakland Tribune|date=October 19, 2011}} The camp grew to roughly 150 tents that were used for both camping and to provide essential services to protesters and visitors. A "miniature city" evolved complete with a kitchen, library, a bicycle-powered media center, and children's village. The grass was strewn with straw and walkways were created using wooden pallets and boards.{{cite news|last=Bernard|first=Sara|title=A day in the life of Occupy Oakland|url=http://kalwnews.org/audio/2011/10/24/day-the-life-occupy-oakland_1376708.html|accessdate=November 29, 2011|newspaper=KALW|date=October 24, 2011}} There were tents dedicated to arts and crafts, medical attention, supplies, and conflict resolution. Activities were scheduled throughout the day including committee meetings, discussion groups, and yoga classes. {{cite news|title='Occupy Oakland' Encampment Becomes Bustling Community|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/10/20/%E2%80%98occupy-oakland%E2%80%99-encampment-becomes-bustling-community/|accessdate=October 23, 2011|publisher=CBS San Francisco|date=October 20, 2011}}Actor and activist [[Danny Glover]] spoke at a rally on October 15. {{cite news|last=Bender|first=Kristen|title=Freed American hikers speak to Occupy Oakland on Monday night|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19132953|accessdate=October 22, 2011|newspaper=San Jose Mercury News|date=October, 22 2011}} Hip hop artist [[Lupe Fiasco]] donated food, supplies, and tents to the protesters the night he played a concert in town.{{cite news|last=Farooq|first=Sajid|title=Lupe Fiasco Donates to Occupy Oakland|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Lupe-Fiasco-Donates-to-Occupy-Oakland-131601463.html|accessdate=October 22, 2011|publisher=NBC Bay Area|date=October 13, 2011}} The grandnephew of labor leader and civil rights activist [[CÃ©sar ChÃ¡vez]] got married at the site on October 20, 2011. Mateus ChÃ¡vez and his fiancÃ© Latrina Rhinehart had not planned to be married at a protest encampment, but as supporters of Occupy Oakland, it made their wedding "that much more meaningful." {{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Scott|title=Officials escalate efforts to remove Occupy Oakland protesters from City Hall|url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/top-stories/ci_19163740|accessdate=November 16, 2011|newspaper=Inside Bay Area|date=October 22, 2011}} On October 22, protesters held a rally at the plaza, marched from the plaza to Snow Park and protested outside a branch of Well Fargo. {{cite news | last=Kuruvila | first=Matthai | title=Occupy Oakland shuts streets, defy eviction order|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/23/MNUU1LL5KR.DTL | date=October 23, 2011 | accessdate=October 25, 2011 | newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle }} =====October 25 police raid & evening protest===== At 4:30 a.m. on October 25, 2011, police officers in [[riot gear]] arrived at the plaza to clear the encampment. About two hundred protesters attempted to defend the camp with a make-shift barricade consisting of crates, metal police barricades and dumpsters. As the police entered the camp, some protesters threw bottles, plates, and other kitchen items. {{cite news |last=Bender |first=Kristen |title=Early morning police raid ousts Occupy Oakland |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/bay-area-news/ci_19188591 |accessdate=October 25, 2011 |newspaper=San Jose Mercury News |date=October 25, 2011}} Two local NBC reporters described the raid as "violent and chaotic at times."{{cite news|last=Farooq|first=Sajid|title=Occupy Oakland Shut Down|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Occupy-Oakland-Gets-Shut-Down-132527503.html|date=October 25, 2011|accessdate=November 24, 2011}} Interim Police Chief Howard Jordan said that [[tear gas]] and [[baton rounds]] were used in response to objects being thrown at officers. One protester saw and heard a [[flash bang grenade]] in the moments before the raid, though Jordan claims they were M-80 and M-1000 firecrackers thrown by protesters. The post-raid scene was described by reporters for the Oakland Tribune as looking like a "hurricane-struck refugee camp." 79 people were arrested, most for unlawful assembly and illegal lodging. {{cite web|title=Additional Details Regarding OPDâs Enforcement in Frank Ogawa Plaza and Snow Park, October 25, 2011|url=http://www2.oaklandnet.com/oakca/groups/ceda/.../oak031908.pdf|publisher=City of Oakland|accessdate=November 25, 2011}} Police erected metal barricades around the perimeter of the plaza as 200-300 protesters gathered around them chanting. {{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland protestors march through Oakland after chaotic day of evictions, arrests|url=http://oaklandnorth.net/2011/10/25/occupy-oakland-protestors-march-through-oakland-after-chaotic-day-of-evictions-arrests/|accessdate=November 25, 2011|newspaper=Oakland North|date=October 25, 2011}} The Oakland Police department along with 500 officers from 17 local law-enforcement agencies participated in the morning raid and evening protection of the plaza under a "mutual aid" agreement. Officers were from the police departments of Alameda, [[Berkeley Police Department|Berkeley]], Emeryville, Fremont, Hayward, Newark, Palo Alto, Pleasanton, [[San Jose Police Department|San Jose]], San Leandro, and Union City, as well as the [[San Francisco Sheriff's Department]], [[Santa Clara County Sheriff's Office]], [[Alameda County Sheriff's Office]], Solano County Sheriff's Office, [[California Highway Patrol]], and the [[University of California Police Department]].{{cite news | url=http://www.paloaltoonline.com/news/show_story.php?id=23012 | date=October 27, 2011 | title=Palo Alto police involved in 'Occupy' incident | publisher=''Palo Alto Online'' }}{{cite news | url=http://www.baycitizen.org/occupy-movement/story/hunt-rubber-bullets-occupy-oakland | date=October 26, 2011 | title=The Hunt for Rubber Bullets at Occupy Oakland | publisher=''The Bay Citizen'' }}{{cite news | url=http://www.dailycal.org/2011/10/27/community-raises-concern-with-berkeley-police-ucpd-involvement-in-occupy-oakland/ | date=October 27, 2011 | title=Community raises concern with Berkeley police, UCPD involvement in Occupy Oakland | newspaper=''The Daily Californian'' }} {{ external media | align = right | width = | video1= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CpO-lJr2BQY Raw Video: Protesters Clash With Oakland Police.]" Footage of woman's arrest at police line. Police firing tear gas at protesters. Oct. 25{{cite web |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CpO-lJr2BQY |title=Raw Video: Protesters Clash With Oakland police |date=October 25, 2011 |publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=October 26, 2011 }} |video2= "[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/video/2011/oct/26/occupy-oakland-tear-gas-protest-video?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3486 Occupy Oakland: teargas fired at protesters.]" Compilation of Oct. 25 clashes. Includes aerial footage of tear gas & flashbangs. {{cite web |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/video/2011/oct/26/occupy-oakland-tear-gas-protest-video?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3486 |title=Occupy Oakland: teargas fired at protesters|date=October 26, 2011 |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=November 26, 2011}} }} At 5 p.m. between 500 and 1,000 people including clergy, students, and union members gathered at the downtown [[Oakland Public Library]] for a rally and march back to the plaza to reclaim the space.{{cite news |last=Gabbatt |first=Adam |title=Occupy Oakland protests - Wednesday 26 October |work=live blog |publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=October 26, 2011|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/oct/26/occupy-oakland-protests-live?CMP=NECNETTXT8187 |accessdate=October 29, 2011}}{{cite audio | people = Kim, Mina(Reporter) | title = [http://blogs.kqed.org/newsfix/2011/10/25/police-arrest-protesters-tear-down-occupy-oakland-tent-city/] | medium = Audio production | publisher = KQED | location = Oakland | date = October 25, 2011 }} At the rally, one reporter noted that "there was a feeling that the way the city responded to the camp was not only out of proportion to the problem, but that it was kind of a waste of money and energy that could be going to address these other issues."{{cite news|last=Miner|first=Casey|title=The scene at Occupy Oakland|url=http://kalwnews.org/audio/2011/10/26/the-scene-occupy-oakland_1388017.html|accessdate=November 29, 2011|newspaper=KALW News|date=October 26, 2011}} On their way, they headed to the Oakland Police Department to protest, and were blocked by a line of riot police. There was a brief standoff and after a police officer forcefully arrested a woman, some protesters threw paint on the police.{{cite news |last=Kuruvila |first=Matthai |title=Police tear gas Occupy Oakland protesters |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |date=October 25, 2011 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/25/BAUB1LLTC9.DTL |accessdate=October 25, 2011}} At 6 p.m. riot police began firing tear gas at the marching protesters.{{cite news|title=Police and Occupy Demonstrators Clash in Oakland|url=http://blogs.kqed.org/newsfix/2011/10/25/police-arrest-protesters-tear-down-occupy-oakland-tent-city/|accessdate=November 27, 2011|newspaper=KQED NewsFix (blog)|date=October 25, 2011}} The protesters continued to regroup and, at one point, sat down with linked arms in the intersection of 14th and Broadway near the plaza. They were declared an unlawful assembly and told to leave or be subject to chemical weapons.{{cite news |last=Wollan |first=Malia |title=Police Fire Tear Gas at Occupy Protesters in Oakland |work=The Lede Blog |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 26, 2011 |url= http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/26/police-said-to-fire-tear-gas-at-protesters-in-oakland-calif/?hp# |accessdate=October 26, 2011}}The march continued around the city until about 9:30 p.m. when the protesters returned again to the plaza which was barricaded and guarded by 100 riot police wearing gas masks. Some protesters threw water bottles and other objects at the police. Police issued dispersal orders then again fired tear gas cannisters, [[baton rounds]] and possibly flashbang grenades and [[CS gas]] at the crowd.{{cite news|title=Iraq War Vet Hospitalized with Fractured Skull After Being Shot by Police at Occupy Oakland Protest|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2011/10/27/iraq_war_vet_hospitalized_with_fractured|accessdate=November 27, 2011|newspaper=Democracy Now|date=October 27, 2011}} Oakland police chief Howard Jordan denied the use of flashbang grenades and said that the explosions came from [[M-80 (explosive)|M-80 firecrackers]] thrown by protesters. Both witnesses and reporters from ''[[The Guardian]]'' described these explosions as looking and sounding like flash-bang devices. Because of the presence of 17 other law enforcement agencies assisting the Oakland police department, Oakland city officials are not aware of exactly what weapons were being used by these outside police agencies, including possibly [[rubber bullet]]s.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} [[#Scott Olsen head injury|Iraq War veteran Scott Olsen]] suffered a [[bone fracture|skull fracture]] caused by a [[projectile]] that witnesses believed was a tear gas or smoke canister fired by the police. He was rushed to the hospital by other protesters, who were shot at with unknown police projectiles while attempting to aid him. At least two other protesters were injured. The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] and [[National Lawyers Guild]] are calling for an investigation into the use of excessive force by Oakland police. Oakland resident Spencer Mills [[Streaming media|live streamed]] the night's events which provided video footage seen by over 60,000 viewers.[http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_19278376] ====Second occupation==== [[File:Occupy Oakland Nov 12 2011 PM 09.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Tents within the [[protest camp]] of Occupy Oakland at [[Frank H. Ogawa Plaza]] on November 12 2011. [[Oakland City Hall]] stands in the background.]] The day after the police raid, October 26, between 1,500 and 3,000 people gathered peacefully for a speak-out and general assembly in the plaza's amphitheater.{{cite news|last=Fagan|first=Kevin|title=Occupy Oakland protesters regroup - Iraq vet hurt|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2011-10-27/news/30331112_1_rubber-bullets-protesters-peaceful-demonstration|accessdate=November 29, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=October 27, 2011}} The grassy area of the plaza was empty and surrounded by chain link fences. The general assembly voted to organize a [[general strike]] for November 2. The fences were torn down by protesters chanting, "Whose park? Our park!" and one tent was erected. Mayor Jean Quan issued a statement urging non-violence and asked that there be no overnight camping; however, the city did not take steps to prevent the re-occupation.{{cite news | last=Bulwa | first=Demian | title=Some tents reappear at Occupy Oakland site | newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle | date=October 28, 2011 | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/28/MNHK1LN717.DTL | accessdate=October 28, 2011 }} The second occupation lasted for 18 days from October 26 to November 14. The "miniature city" was re-created with the addition of an interfaith tent and grew to about 180 tents.{{cite news|last=Fagan|first=Kevin|title=Occupy Oakland campers defy city demand to leave|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/11/BAOI1LTP11.DTL|accessdate=November 15, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 12, 2011}} The city of Oakland distributed notices of violation to protesters for three days from November 11 through November 13. The notices stated that the protesters where in violation of the law by lodging overnight, obstructing the use of a public park, and making fires in a public park.{{cite web|title=Bulletins Distributed to Occupy Oakland Demonstators|url=http://www2.oaklandnet.com/OAK031910|publisher=City of Oakland|accessdate=15 November 2011}} Law enforcement cleared the camp the morning of November 14. ===Snow Park=== Snow Park, a small park beside Lake Merritt, was established on October 18 with about two dozen people occupying the park after Frank Ogawa Plaza had filled up with tents.{{cite news | last=Alston | first=John | title='Occupy Oakland' takes over a second park | url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8396951 | accessdate=October 23, 2011 | publisher=KGO | date=October 18, 2011}} {{cite news|last=Bulwa|first=Demian|title=Occupy Oakland looking to expand|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/18/MNMU1LJ2JA.DTL|accessdate=October 20, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=October 19, 2011}} The Snow Park protesters initially spent time maintaining the grounds of the park. They were removed from the park by law enforcement on the morning of October 25, an hour after Frank Ogawa Plaza was raided. Six protesters were arrested. The camp was reestablished with one tent erected on October 26 or 27.{{cite news|last=Anthony|first=Laura|title='Occupy' tents back up in Frank Ogawa Plaza|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8408177|accessdate=November 29, 2011|newspaper=KGO-TV|date=October 28, 2011}} The encampment grew to about 20 tents by November 13. {{cite news | last=Kristin J. | first=Bender | title=Police hand out another round of Occupy Oakland evictions | url=http://www.mercurynews.com/occupy-oakland/ci_19323275 | accessdate=November 13, 2011 | publisher=Mercury News | date=November 12, 2011}} On November 21, 100 campers peacefully left Snow Park after law enforcement arrived. ===Veterans Camp=== About seven protesters with set up camp in front of the Veterans Memorial Building near the intersection of Harrison and Grand on Veterans Day, November 11. They were cleared out by law enforcement on November 14. {{cite news|title=Live Blog: Some SF occupiers pack up belongings|url=http://www.contracostatimes.com/top-stories/ci_19339609|accessdate=November 21, 2011|newspaper=Contra Costa Times|date=November 16, 2011}} ==Local government reaction== The reaction of local politicians and city officials was mostly positive at first. In fact, Oakland councilwoman Desley Brooks was among the protestors sleeping in tents on the inaugural night of the encampment.{{cite web|last=Maher|first=Sean|title=Councilmember camps overnight with Occupy Oakland protesters|url=http://www.contracostatimes.com/my-town/ci_19087485|work=Contra Costa Times|publisher=[[Oakland Tribune]]|accessdate=22 November 2011|month=October 11|year=2011}} Councilwoman Jane Brunner expressed support for the movement by stating, "It's about time people are speaking up." {{cite news|last=Kuruvila|first=Mattai|title=Occupy movement in Oakland, SF housing protest|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/10/BA5T1LFU78.DTL&feed=rss.bayarea|accessdate=October 18, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=October 11, 2011}} Mayor [[Jean Quan]] visited the protest site the next day on October 11, 2011, and "condoned the occupation".{{cite web|title=Wide Range Of Causes Fuel âOccupy Oaklandâ Protests|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/10/11/wide-range-of-causes-fuel-occupy-oakland-protests/|work=CBS San Fransico|publisher=CBS Local Media|accessdate=22 November 2011|month=October 11|year=2011}} City administrator spokeswoman Karen Boyd said that the city's plan was to let the protesters stay "As long as they are peaceful and respectful of the rights of all the users of the plaza.". Bay Area [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] members [[Barbara Lee]] and [[Pete Stark]] also released statements of support. The [[Alameda County]] Health Department inspected the camp on October 19. {{cite news|last=Maher|first=Sean|title=Rats and drugs mar Occupy Oakland tent city, officials say|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/bay-area-news/ci_19139574|accessdate=October 23, 2011|newspaper=San Jose Mercury News|date=October 19, 2011}} The next day, October 20, the City of Oakland published and distributed an official notice of violation citing the camp for fire, safety, and sanitation hazards.{{cite web|title=Notice to Vacate Frank Ogawa Plaza, October 20|url=http://www2.oaklandnet.com/oakca/groups/cityadministrator/documents/procedure/oak031803.pdf|accessdate=November 24, 2011|author=City of Oakland|format=PDF}} The city issued violation notices threatening arrest for the next few days. {{cite web|title=Notice of Violations and Demand to Cease Violations, October 21|url=http://www.indybay.org/uploads/2011/10/21/occupyoakland_arrestwarning_oak031873.pdf|accessdate=November 24, 2011|author=City of Oakland|format=PDF}}{{cite web|title=Notice of Violations and Demand to Cease Violations, October 22|url=http://www.indybay.org/uploads/2011/10/22/occupyoakland_arrestwarning-ogawa_102211_oak031875.pdf|accessdate=November 24, 2011|author=City of Oakland|format=PDF}}{{cite web|title=Notice of Violations and Demand to Cease Violations, October 24|url=http://www.indybay.org/uploads/2011/10/24/occupyoakland_arrestwarning-ogawa_1024411_oak031895.pdf|accessdate=November 24, 2011|author=City of Oakland|format=PDF}} The 300 to 400 demonstrators "appeared determined not to leave" and countered that "complaints about rats, drug crimes and violence in the area of 14th Street and Broadway went unchecked before they arrived."{{cite news|last=Fagan|first=Kevin|title=Occupy Oakland says it's not going anywhere|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/21/BA6S1LKNVB.DTL&tsp=1|accessdate=October 22, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=October 22, 2011}} In response to the mayor's support for the November 2 general strike, the Oakland Police Officer's Association issued an [http://www.opoa.org/uncategorized/an-open-letter-to-the-citizens-of-oakland-from-the-oakland-police-officers%E2%80%99-association/ open letter] to the citizens of Oakland expressing "confusion" about Mayor Quan's decision making.{{cite news|last=Fagan|first=Kevin|title=Oakland police union: 'We are confused' by Quan|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/01/BAOS1LP3SB.DTL&tsp=1|accessdate=November 2, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 2, 2011}} The open letter took issue with Mayor Quan's decision to allow public employees to participate in the upcoming general strike:
[T]he Administration issued a memo on Friday, October 28th to all City workers in support of the âStop Workâ strike scheduled for Wednesday, giving all employees, except for police officers, permission to take the day off. Thatâs hundreds of City workers encouraged to take off work to participate in the protest against âthe establishment.â But arenât the Mayor and her Administration part of the establishment they are paying City employees to protest?
==Incidents of alleged police misconduct== ===Scott Olsen head injury=== {{ external media | align = right | width = | video1= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QngE6kKk8Lg Occupy Oakland video: Riot police fire tear gas, flashbang grenades.]" Oakland police fire tear gas against protesters. Oct. 25. Scott Olsen can be seen being evacuated at :58{{mdash}}1:23.{{cite web |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QngE6kKk8Lg |title=Occupy Oakland video: Riot police fire tear gas, flashbang grenades |date=October 25, 2011 |publisher=Russia Today |accessdate=October 26, 2011}} | video2= "[http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2011/11/28/18701164.php Occupy Oakland video: Interview with Scott Olsen About His Injury from the Police Attack on October 25th, 2011.]" Scott Olsen discusses the events of Oct 25th, his injuries, and the Oakland police department investigation {{cite web |url=http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2011/11/28/18701164.php |title=Occupy Oakland video: Interview with Scott Olsen About His Injury from the Police Attack on October 25th, 2011 |date=November 27th, 2011 |publisher=Dave Id Indybay.org |accessdate=December 1st, 2011}} }} On October 25, 2011, Scott Olsen, a former [[United States Marine Corps|Marine]] and [[Iraq War]] veteran, and a member of [[Veterans for Peace]], suffered a [[bone fracture|skull fracture]] caused by a [[projectile]] that witnesses believed was a tear gas or smoke canister fired by the police.{{cite news | last=Henderson | first=Peter | last2=Randewich | first2=Noel | title=Oakland protesters plan march, mayor apologizes |publisher=Reuters | date=October 29, 2011 | url= http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/29/us-usa-wallstreet-protests-oakland-idUSTRE79R5LH20111029 | accessdate=October 29, 2011 | quote=Olsen, 24, [...], was struck in the head by a tear gas canister fired on Tuesday by police, protest organizers said. }}{{cite news | last=Flock | first=Elizabeth | title=Iraq veteran Scott Olsen now in 'fair' condition | work=blogPOST | publisher=[[Washington Post]] | date=October 27, 2011 | url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/blogpost/post/occupy-oakland-veteran-scott-olsens-injuries-prompt-internal-police-review/2011/10/27/gIQAVrs1LM_blog.html | accessdate=October 29, 2011 }} A video by protesters has surfaced showing the explosion of what appears to be a flash-bang device thrown by one officer near protesters attempting to aid Olsen.{{cite news | last=Gabbatt | first=Adam | title=Scott Olsen injuries prompt review as Occupy Oakland protests continue | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | location=United Kingdom | date=October 26, 2011 | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/oct/26/scott-olsen-occupy-oakland-review | accessdate=October 29, 2011 }} The [[Associated Press]] later reported that it was not known exactly what kind of object had struck Olsen or who had thrown or fired it, but that protesters had been throwing rocks and bottles.{{cite news | url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-10-26/news/30324625_1_protesters-police-officers-demonstrators | title=Iraq war vet injured during Oakland protests | publisher=Boston.com | date=October 26, 2011 | deadurl=yes }} {{Dead link|date=November 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that a projectile found near where Olsen fell was a so-called "[[bean bag round]]". Olsen was rushed to the hospital by other protesters, who were fired upon with unknown police projectiles while attempting to aid him.{{cite news |author=Adam Gabbatt |title=Occupy Oakland: Iraq war veteran in critical condition after police clashes |publisher=The Guardian |date=October 26, 2011 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/oct/26/occupy-oakland-veteran-critical-condition |accessdate=October 29, 2011 |location=London}}{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=David|title=Marine Veteran Injured by Non-Lethal Rounds at Occupy Oakland|url=http://www.veteranstoday.com/2011/10/26/marine-veteran-injured-by-non-lethal-rounds-at-occupy-oakland/|publisher=[[Veterans Today]]|accessdate=22 November 2011|month=October 26|year=2011}} Doctors said that he was in [[medical state|critical condition]]. At least two other protesters were injured. The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] and [[National Lawyers Guild]] are calling for an investigation into the use of excessive force by Oakland police.{{cite news |last=Bender |first=Kristen |title=Occupy Oakland protesters return downtown to claim Frank Ogawa Plaza |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_19197518 |accessdate=October 27, 2011 |newspaper=Oakland Tribune |date=October 26, 2011}} However, the investigation by the Citizens Police Review Board is expected to last several months. {{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland: police to be investigated over Scott Olsen injury|last=Gabbat|first=Adam|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/01/occupy-oakland-police-scott-olsen|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=November 1, 2011}} Olsen was released from the hospital around November 10, and is gradually recovering from his injuries, but has difficulty speaking. On November 14, he posted a statement on a social networking site stating, "After my freedom of speech was quite literally taken from me, my speech is coming back but I've got a lot of work to do with rehab."{{cite news|title=Scott Olsen makes first public statement since Occupy Oakland injury|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/14/scott-olsen-first-statement-occupy-oakland|accessdate=November 17, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 14, 2011|location=London}} Details regarding Olsen's time in the U.S. Marines are emerging. He served two tours of duty in the [[Iraq War]] and received an [[Military discharge|administrative discharge]] in 2009. He later became disillusioned with the Marines and created a now-defunct web site called, "I hate the Marine Corps". News of his injury helped inspire the formation of [[Occupy Marines]].[http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/offduty/travel/offduty-occupy-protests-lure-vets-111711/ Jon R. Anderson, ââOccupyâ protests lure vetsâ, Marine Corps Times, 18 November 2011] A video interview with Olsen, the first since his injury, was published on the San Francisco Bay Area Independent Media Center web site. {{cite web|title=Interview with Scott Olsen About His Injury from the Police Attack on Occupy Oakland: video|url=http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2011/11/28/18701164.php|publisher=Indybay.org|accessdate=December 2, 2011}}
===Scott Campbell shooting=== {{ external media | align = right | width = | video1= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I0pX9LeE-g8 Shot by police with rubber bullet at Occupy Oakland]" Filmed by Oakland resident Scott Campbell, moments before being shot by an Oakland Police officer. }} Shortly before 1am on November 3, Oakland resident Scott Campbell was shot by police using a [[Non-lethal weapon#Ammunition|less-lethal round]] while he was filming a stationary line of police in riot gear, hours after the [[2011 Oakland general strike]]. The apparently-unprovoked shooting was documented by the resulting point-of-view video from Campbell's own camera.[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57321440/experts-occupy-vid-shows-excessive-force/ Experts: "Occupy" video shows excessive force] Geoffrey Alpert, a criminal justice professor from the University of South Carolina said watching a video of the incident left him "astonished, amazed and embarrassed" and that "unless there's something we don't know, that's one of the most outrageous uses of a firearm that I've ever seen."{{cite web|title=Experts in police use of force shocked by Oakland video|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19284774|work=Republished by Mercury News|publisher=[[Oakland Tribune]]|accessdate=22 November 2011|author=Josh Richman|coauthors=Thomas Peele|month=November 7|year=2011}} ===Kayvan Sabeghi beating=== {{ external media | align = right | width = | video1= "[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/video/2011/nov/18/occupy-oakland-veteran-beaten-police-video Iraq war veteran Kayvan Sabehgi beaten by a police officer]" }} Kayvan Sabeghi, a local business owner and former [[United States Army Rangers|U.S. Army Ranger]] who served in the [[Iraq War]] and the [[War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)|War in Afghanistan]], was hit numerous times by a police officer with a baton then arrested on the evening of November 2. {{cite news|last=Gabbatt|first=Adam|title=Occupy Oakland: footage shows police beating 'peaceful' Iraq war veteran|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/video/2011/nov/18/occupy-oakland-veteran-beaten-police-video|accessdate=November 21, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 18, 2011|location=London}} Sabeghi was charged with resisting arrest and remaining at the scene of a riot. While in police custody, Sabeghi complained of severe pain and asked for medical treatment but was transferred to [[Highland Hospital (Oakland, California)|Highland Hospital]] 14-18 hours after his arrest. Sabeghi underwent emergency surgery for a ruptured spleen and remained in the intensive care unit. {{cite news|last=Randewich|first=Noel|title=Army veteran injured in Oakland clashes with police|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/05/us-protests-oakland-veteran-idUSTRE7A37A820111105|accessdate=6 November 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=4 November 2011}} The organization [[Iraq Veterans Against the War]] issued a statement on November 4 stating, "police struck Sabeghi with nightsticks on his hands, shoulders, ribs and back, and that in addition to a lacerated [[spleen]] he suffered from internal bleeding" {{cite news|last=Gabbatt|first=Adam|title=Occupy Oakland: second Iraq war veteran injured after police clashes|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/04/occupy-oakland-second-veteran-injured|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 4, 2011|location=London}}, a description that is corroborated by the video made available on November 18. The Oakland Police Department is "investigating the incident." ===Susie Cagle arrest and imprisonment=== Although she was obviously wearing a press pass, Journalist Susie Cagle was arrested in the early hours of November 3 and spent 14 hours at 2 different jails. {{cite news|last=Daetz|first=Ama|title=Journalist arrested while covering Oakland protest|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8418546|accessdate=November 21, 2011|newspaper=KGO-TV|date=November 3, 2011}} She was charged with failure to leave the scene of a riot. Journalists' rights in the United States are constitutionally protected through the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution#Freedom of the press|First Amendment]]. Cagle is one of several journalists covering the Occupy movement that have been arrested. {{cite news|title=Human Rights Group Condemns Journalist Arrests At Occupy Protests|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/17/human-rights-group-condem_n_1100282.html|accessdate=November 21, 2011|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=November 17, 2011}} Additionally, Cagle reported having been subject to and witness to mistreatment of protestors during her imprisonment.[http://www.alternet.org/story/152990/police_state_in_oakland_one_reporter%27s_arrest_contradicts_official_story/?page=entire] ===Protesters injured by car=== {{ external media | align = right | width = | video1= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P_JnuV_K4IU Protesters struck by vehicle]" Footage of the incident }} During the evening march to the Port of Oakland as part of the [[2011 Oakland general strike|general strike]] on November 2, the driver of a silver Mercedes-Benz was headed south on 11th Street when he encountered a stream of protesters walking along Broadway. Cell phone video footage shows the driver of the Mercedes attempting to drive through the intersection as the march is happening prompting one protester, Lance Laverdure, to jump in front of the car and bang on the hood.KGO [http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8429027#&cmp=twi-kgo-article-8429027 Protesters hit by car press for driver's arrest] The driver hit the gas and both Laverdure and a nearby protester Margaret So were hit by the car and sustained leg and ankle injuries. Nearby witnesses then surrounded the car as emergency personnel attended to the protesters. The driver was questioned by BART police and released, angering witnesses who called for the driver's arrest.{{cite news|last=Kuruvila|first=Matthai|title=Mercedes hits 2 Occupy Oakland protesters|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/03/BA5G1LQ06S.DTL|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 3, 2011}} The two protesters suffered leg and ankle injuries and were taken to Highland Hospital. On November 11, the two victims held a press conference alleging that the incident was a criminal act and questioned why the Oakland Police Department had not prosecuted the driver. Victims said that nine days after the incident, they still had not been contacted by police. Lance Laverdure told press that, "We want this person arrested for the attempted murder of myself and Margaret". ==Solidarity with local Occupy movements== Occupy Oakland protesters have joined the [[Occupy Cal]] demonstrations at UC Berkeley.{{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland protesters march to Berkeley|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/news/ci_19342690|accessdate=November 17, 2011|newspaper=Associated Press|date=November 15, 2011}} ==Chronology of events== {{main|Timeline of Occupy Oakland}}{{See also|Timeline of Occupy Wall Street}} ===Weeks 1 - 4 (October 10 - November 6)=== Occupy Oakland began on October 10, 2011, with a rally attended by hundreds and protest encampment of a couple dozen tents at Frank Ogawa Plaza. On October 15, 2011, around 2,500 people, including actor [[Danny Glover]], came out for a Saturday march and rally to show their support for Occupy Oakland.{{cite news|title=Organizers say thousands took part in Oakland rally|url=http://www.ktvu.com/news/29497557/detail.html|accessdate=October 18, 2011|newspaper=KTVU|date=October 15, 2011}} A second camp with about two dozen people was set up on October 18 at Snow Park near Lake Merritt.{{cite news|last=Alston|first=John|title='Occupy Oakland' takes over a second park|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8396951|accessdate=October 23, 2011|publisher=KGO|date=October 18, 2011}} From October 20 through October 24, the City of Oakland distributed official notices to the protesters citing "violence, assaults, threats and intimidation", among other complaints, and, forbidding lodging overnight.{{cite news|last=McCleese|first=Tihanna|title='Occupy Oakland' protesters given ultimatum|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8400403|accessdate=October 21, 2011|publisher=KGO|date=October 20, 2011}} The demonstrators "appeared determined not to leave" and countered that "the rats, drug crimes, and violence in the area of 14th Street and Broadway went unchecked before they arrived." {{cite news|last=Fagan|first=Kevin|title=Occupy Oakland says it's not going anywhere|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/21/BA6S1LKNVB.DTL&tsp=1|accessdate=October 22, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=October 22, 2011}} On October 25, 2011, police officers in [[riot gear]] from various [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] law enforcement agencies cleared the plaza and Snow Park during the early hours of the day. That evening, as protesters attempted to re-occupy the plaza, violence between the police and protesters resulted in [[#Scott Olsen head injury|Iraq War veteran Scott Olsen]]'s head injury. [[File:Occupy Oakland protesters Oct 30.png|thumb|right|300px|Protesters retreating east on 14th Street toward Lake Merritt after Oakland Police attempted to disperse them from Downtown with [[less lethal]] weapons.]] Between 1,500 and 3,000 people gathered peacefully at the plaza on October 26, 2011. The plaza was re-taken by protesters with at least one tent erected that evening. The general assembly voted to organize a [[general strike]] for November 2. About 2,000 people held a candlelight vigil for Scott Olsen at the plaza on October 27, 2011. {{cite news|title=Scott Olsen Vigil Attended By Thousands, Mayor Quan Booed|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/10/28/scott-olsen-vigil_n_1064185.html|accessdate=November 23, 2011|publisher=Huffington Post|date=October 28, 2011}} Documentary filmmaker [[Michael Moore]] spoke to a crowd of about 1,000 protesters on October 28, 2011. In the hour-long address, Michael Moore encouraged Occupy Oakland by saying, "We've killed despair across the country and we've killed apathy." {{cite news | title=Michael Moore: Occupy movement "killed apathy" | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-20127435/michael-moore-occupy-movement-killed-apathy/ | accessdate=October 29, 2011 | publisher=CBS News | date=October 29, 2011 }} Dozens of new tents have been erected in the plaza, including a medical tent provided and staffed by the [[California Nurses Association/National Nurses Organizing Committee|California Nurses Association]].{{cite news | last=Kuruvila | first=Matthai | title=Occupy Oakland: inspiration, frustration at return | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/29/MN951LNTGB.DTL | accessdate=October 29, 2011 | newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle | date=October 29, 2011 }} Pro-democracy protesters in Egypt marched from Cairo's [[Tahrir Square]] to the U.S. Embassy in solidarity with Occupy Oakland. {{cite news | title=Egyptians March for Occupy Oakland | url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/politics/132802458.html | accessdate=October 28, 2011 | publisher=NBC Bay Area | date=October 28, 2011 }} Representatives of Occupy Oakland held a press conference detailing plans for the general strike on November 2.{{cite news|title=Oakland braces for Occupy movement's call for general strike|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/11/oakland-braces-citywide-general-strike-.html|accessdate=November 1, 2011|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=November 1, 2011}} The Oakland Police Officer's Association issued an [http://www.opoa.org/uncategorized/an-open-letter-to-the-citizens-of-oakland-from-the-oakland-police-officers%E2%80%99-association/ open letter] to the citizens of Oakland expressing "confusion" about Mayor Quan's decision making in relation to the general strike. [[File:Oakland General Strike 2011-11-02.jpg|thumb|One of the marches to the Port of Oakland during the [[2011 Oakland General Strike]] on Nov. 2, 2011]] Thousands of protesters gathered at Frank Ogawa Plaza to participate in rallies, marches, and teach-ins designed to empower citizens and to draw attention to economic inequity and corporate greed as part of the [[2011 Oakland General Strike]]. {{cite news|title=California protesters shut down Oakland port|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/02/occuply-oakland-general-strike-live|accessdate=November 3, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|publisher=The Guardian News Blog|location=London|first=Matt|last=Wells}} Local unions expressed solidarity for the [[strike action|strike]] including Oakland's largest union, [[Service Employees International Union|Service Employees International Union]] Local 1021, Oakland Education Association, [[International Longshore and Warehouse Union|International Longshore and Warehouse Union]] Local 10, and [[United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America|United Brotherhood of Carpenters]]. While none of the unions were officially on strike, many urged their members to take a personal day, vacation day or to participate after work. {{cite news|last=Gee|first=Robyn|title=Teachers, Service Workers Support Oakland's Strike Without Striking|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/turnstyle/teachers-service-workers_b_1071604.html|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=November 2, 2011}} While most of the day-time activities were peaceful, Oakland Police chief Howard Jordan reported that a small group of "anarchists" vandalized a [[Whole Foods]] storefront, and broke windows and [[Automated teller machine|ATM]]s of [[Bank of America]] and [[Wells Fargo]] banks in the afternoon. {{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland General Strike Shuts Down Port; Anarchists âBent On Creating Problemsâ|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/11/02/general-strike-protesters-shut-down-port-of-oakland/|accessdate=3 November 2011|publisher=CBS San Francisco|date=2 November 2011}} [http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19246904 At least 4,000 are at the gates to the Port of Oakland] Many buildings were vandalized, including some businesses that displayed signs of support for the General Strike. After the incidents of vandalism, members of Occupy Oakland organized to guard local businesses, board up broken windows, and clean graffiti caused by the [[black bloc]] vandals. Oakland mayor Jean Quan described the vandals as "a small and isolated group" that "shouldn't mar the overall impact of the demonstration and the fact that people in the 99 percent movement demonstrated peacefully and, for the most part, were productive and very peaceful."{{cite news| url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2011%2F11%2F03%2FBACM1LQ5FU.DTL | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | first=Henry K. | last=Lee | title=Developer with shotgun scared off Oakland rioters | date=November 4, 2011}} Thousands of protesters marched from Frank Ogawa Plaza to the [[Port of Oakland]], the fifth busiest port in the United States, in two separate groups leaving the plaza at 4:00 pm and 5:00 pm. The number of protesters marching to the port has not been confirmed. While police estimate 7,000 people marched, local organizers {{cite news|title=Video Report from Streets of Oakland: First General Strike in City Since 1946 Shuts Down Major Port|url=http://www.democracynow.org/seo/2011/11/3/video_report_from_streets_of_oakland|accessdate=November 6, 2011|publisher=Democracy Now|date=November 3, 2011}} and participants {{cite news|last=Abraham|first=Zennie|title=Occupy Oakland Strike Draws 100,000; Violence Caused By 100|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/abraham/2011/11/03/occupy-oakland-strike-draws-100000-violence-caused-by-100/|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle - Blog|date=November 1, 2003}} put the number somewhere between 20,000 and 100,000. As protesters completely filled Middle Harbor Road, the main road leading to the port, all truck traffic entering or exiting the port was halted. Port operations were "effectively shut down" a couple hours later. {{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland throng closes down port|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/03/MN8Q1LPI1J.DTL|accessdate=November 3, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|newspaper=The San Francisco Chronicle|first1=Demian|last1=Bulwa|first2=Matthai|last2=Kuruvila|first3=Kevin|last3=Fagan}} Later in the evening, a group of protesters took over a vacant building that once served as the headquarters of the Traveler's Aid Society, a non-profit organization that provided services to the local homeless population. Police soon arrived to break up the protesters gathered outside of the building. Some protesters fled while others set a barricade on fire. {{cite news|last=Loftis|first=Emily|title=Occupy Oakland shuts down port|url=http://www.salon.com/2011/11/03/occupy_oakland_shuts_down_port/|accessdate=November 4, 2011|newspaper=Salon|date=November 3, 2011}} Police used teargas and flash bangs to try to clear protesters. At least one man was carried away injured after protesters said he was shot in the leg by a rubber bullet. {{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland general strike â Thursday 3 November|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/03/occupy-oakland-general-strike-live#block-13|accessdate=November 3, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|location=London|first=Haroon|last=Siddique}} Clashes continued past midnight. 103 people were arrested. {{ external media | align = left | width = | video1= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CQl0g2Rqyfs CA Violence: RT footage from 'occupied' Oakland]" Compilation of events as Oakland police begin using tear gas to disperse crowds, while protesters retreat from the police line, treat those effected by gas, break windows at nearby businesses, or provide film interviews. | video2= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MnBGaru-nxQ More RT footage: Riot cops tear gas Occupy Oakland strike]" Further compilation of events. }} Various reports of police using excessive force later emerged, including a first-person-perspective video of a protester being shot by police, reports of a second Iraq war veteran hospitalized for injury sustained during arrest, and a journalist who after being swept up in mass arrests with protesters, witnessed acts of police brutality. On November 5, the City Council met to consider a resolution by council member [[Nancy Nadel]] in support of the Occupy Oakland encampment. After listening to over 100 members of the public, the council postponed its vote until November 15. {{cite news|title=Tense Meeting Reveals Deep Divisions over Occupy Oakland|url=http://www.baycitizen.org/occupy-movement/story/tense-meeting-reveals-deep-divisions/|accessdate=November 5, 2011|publisher=The Bay Citizen|date=November 4, 2011}} A downtown Oakland Wells Fargo branch closed for business because of the roughly 100 immigrant rights protesters who marched from Occupy Oakland's encampment to protest the bank's connection to companies that run [[Immigration detention in the United States|immigrant detention centers]]. {{cite news|last=Wohlsen|first=Marcus|title=Protesters close down Oakland Wells Fargo branch|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/11/05/state/n134250D33.DTL|accessdate=November 5, 2011|newspaper=AP - San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 5, 2011}} ===Weeks 5 - 7 (November 7 â November 27)=== On November 7, Occupy Oakland accepted a $20,000 donation for urgent medical and legal expenses from Occupy Wall Street. The money was deposited into an Occupy Oakland lawyer's Wells Fargo bank account. The Occupy Oakland general assembly approved the decision to hold the money temporarily in a Wells Fargo account to be used immediately for bailing out jailed protesters. When the group's status as an unincorporated association is approved, the money will be transferred to a local credit union. This deposit was seen by some news outlets and some Occupy Oakland protesters as hypocritical because just a few days earlier, Occupy Oakland had protested against Wells Fargo. Wells Fargo spokesman Ruben Pulido said, "If this report is true, it demonstrates that even Occupy Oakland understands â firsthand â the value and service that Wells Fargo provides its customers. Wells Fargo welcomes the 100 percent of Americans to allow us to help them meet their financial needs."[http://www.sfexaminer.com/local/2011/11/occupy-oakland-makes-20k-deposit-wells-fargo Occupy Oakland makes $20K deposit at Wells Fargo], San Francisco Examiner, November 8, 2011[http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/11/09/occupy-oakland-protesters-deposit-funds-at-wells-fargo-after-bank-attacks/ Occupy Oakland Protesters Deposit Funds At Wells Fargo After Bank Attacks], CBS News, November 9, 2011 On November 9, five members of the Oakland City Council, Desley Brooks, [[Ignacio De La Fuente]], Pat Kernighan, Libby Schaaf, Larry Reid, two dozen clergy, and Oakland business owners held a press conference calling for the immediate eviction of Occupy Oakland. The group alleged that the ongoing protest had harmed the economy of downtown Oakland, and cited reports of fire hazards in the camp. Occupy protesters interrupted the press conference by chanting, "We are the 99 percent of Oakland." The council members counter chanted: "Occupy Oakland must go." The press conference ended earlier than anticipated.Kuruvila, Matthai [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/09/BAH61LSRPF.DTL Occupy protesters shout down Oakland council] ''San Francisco Chronicle'' November 9, 2011 [[File:Nov19 MassRally occupy oakland.jpg|thumb|left|Occupy Oakland poster advertising November 19 "Mass Rally & March" on 14 and Broadway, released on the Occupy Oakland website November 15.{{cite web|title=Occupy Oakland Blog: Saturday Nov 19 Day of Action: Into the Streets!|url=http://www.occupyoakland.org/2011/11/saturday-nov-19-day-of-action-into-the-streets/|accessdate=17 November 2011|author=Bruce Paul|month=November|year=2011}}]] On November 10, the one-month anniversary of the Occupy Oakland demonstration, a man was fatally shot about 25 yards away from the plaza's tent encampment.{{cite news|last=Walter|first=Shoshana|title=Occupy Oakland and News Media Coexist Uneasily|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/13/us/occupy-oakland-and-news-media-coexist-uneasily.html|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=13 November 2011|date=November 12, 2011}} Occupy Oakland medics responded to the victim until the police and paramedics arrived. Initially, there were mixed reports about whether the people involved in the shooting were connected to Occupy Oakland,{{cite web|last=Kaste|first=Martin|title=Occupy Oakland Movement Tries To Regroup After Shooting|url=http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2011/11/11/142255723/occupy-oakland-movement-tries-to-regroup-after-shooting|publisher=NPR|accessdate=13 November 2011}} and many occupiers felt that the incident had unfairly become a catalyst for their removal. Police later determined that the victim, 25-year-old Kayode Ola Foster, was indeed an Occupy Oakland participant for the previous few days, as was one of two possible murder suspects.{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/11/shooting-victim-tied-to-occupy-oakland.html |title=Shooting victim is tied to Occupy Oakland |last=Romney |first=Lee |date=November 13, 2011 |work=Los Angeles Times}}{{cite web|last=Schwartz|first=Carly|title=Kayode Ola Foster, Man Slain Near Occupy Oakland, Was A Camp Resident|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/14/kayode-ola-foster-occupy-oakland_n_1093412.html|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=15 November 2011}} In response to the shooting, demonstrators observed a moment of silence, prayer, and held a candlelight vigil for the victim, led by one of the camp chaplains.{{cite news|title=Shots fired near 'Occupy Oakland,' one dead|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8427634|accessdate=November 10, 2011|newspaper=KGO-TV|date=November 13, 2011}} [[File:Occupy Oakland - Nov 14 - allegedly badgeless officers.jpg|thumb|November 14 - Police in riot gear[http://redgreenandblue.org/2011/11/14/overwhelming-force-arrayed-against-occupy-oakland/]]] In the days preceding November 14, Oakland Police delivered 'notices of violations' to Frank Ogawa plaza. In the early hours of November 14, approximately 700-1000 police were mobilized. Supporters began arriving, and and a line of union workers wearing white arm bands formed a line to observe and mediate if necessary.{{cite web|last=Bender|first=Kristin J.|title=Occupy Oakland Live Blog: Police outnumber protesters at Ogawa plaza|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/occupy-oakland/ci_19331752|publisher=Mercury News|accessdate=16 November 2011|author=Josh Richman, Thomas Peele and Sean Maher|month=November|year=2011}} At approximately 4:30 AM, police entered the plaza. Police initially made about 20 arrests, 14 of whom had been praying all night in the campâs inter faith tent. Afterwards, police demolished the camp. [[Daniel Mark Siegel|Dan Siegel]], Mayor Jean Quan's city hall Legal Adviser, resigned in protest, announcing, via Facebook: "No longer Mayor Quan's legal adviser. Resigned at 2 am. Support Occupy Oakland, not the 1% and its government facilitators." That same day, Oakland Deputy Mayor [[Sharon Cornu]] resigned her post as well. On November 15, the Occupy Oakland website released a flyer and information about a planned "Mass Rally & March" through Oakland due to take place November 19 to "expand the [[Occupy movement|Occupy Movement]]". The website states the flyer was created in response to calls by the Occupy Oakland General Assembly convened on 11.11.11. On the morning of November 21 the last Occupy camp at Snow Park was dismantled by the city. The roughly 100 protestors left behind nearly 21 truckloads of debris. The movement was left with no physical presence occupying any public space overnight in the city of Oakland. ==See also== {{Columns-list|2| '''Occupy articles''' *[[List of Occupy movement protest locations|List of global Occupy protest locations]] *[[Occupy movement]] *[[We are the 99%]] '''Other U.S. protests''' *[[BART Police shooting of Oscar Grant#Riot 2009|2009 Oakland riots]] *[[2011 United States public employee protests]] *[[2011 Wisconsin protests]] '''Related articles''' * [[Economic inequality]] * [[Income inequality in the United States]] * [[Wealth inequality in the United States]] * [[Plutocracy]] * [[Tea Party protests]] }} {{Portal bar|Social movements|Politics|Business and economics|San Francisco Bay Area|California|United States}} ==References== {{reflist|2|refs= {{cite news | url=http://rt.com/news/occupy-oakland-protest-violence-773/ | title=Occupy Oakland: Tear gas & flashbang grenades | accessdate=October 26, 2011 | publisher=RT | date=October 26, 2011 }} }} ==External links== {{Commons category|Occupy Oakland}} *{{Official website|1=http://www.occupyoakland.org}} *[http://oaklandsnowpark.wordpress.com/ Occupy Snow Park] *[http://ScottOlsen.org/ ScottOlsen.org] {{Occupy movement}} {{Oakland, California}} [[Category:2011 in California]] [[Category:History of Oakland, California]] [[Category:Police brutality in California]] [[Category:Occupy movement in the United States]] [[Category:Occupy Oakland]]
